description: Borrowed from Ancient Greek κῶμα (kôma, “deep sleep”).

entries.meaning: A state of unconsciousness from which one may not wake up, usually induced by some form of trauma.

description: Borrowed from Latin coma (“hair of the head”), from Ancient Greek κόμη (kómē, “hair”).

entries.meaning: (astronomy) A cloud of dust surrounding the nucleus of a comet.
(optics) A defect characterized by diffuse, pear-shaped images that in an ideal image would appear as points.

(botany) A tuft or bunch, such as the assemblage of branches forming the head of a tree, a cluster of bracts when empty and terminating the inflorescence of a plant, or a tuft of long hairs on certain seeds.
